title: Swallowing Trouble with Myasthenia Gravis

content: If you've followed my blog for long, you may know one of the main symptoms of myasthenia gravis (MG) is difficulty swallowing. Yes, your throat and tongue are muscles.
Swallowing involves a lot of work from our muscles. Oh, and also chewing!
This was something I’d never thought about prior to being diagnosed. We never think about how we swallow, right?
Well, it was one of my first symptoms of MG. In the fall of 2022, there were several times I caught myself thinking I had an allergic reaction to something or got stung in my throat by an insect.

I never had allergies growing up, but I started researching if they can suddenly show up. I learned that’s a possibility. So that was my initial reaction, on top of other symptoms I’d never linked to difficulty swallowing.

My first MG symptom was weakness in my fingers and arms.Then my left eye started to droop. Little did I know, after four visits to the ER in one week, I’d be diagnosed with a chronic illness  and stuck in the ICU for a month trying to survive.

content: In the ICU, I couldn’t eat anything for four weeks. My muscles had weakened and I was at risk of choking. I was followed by an occupational therapist until I got better and I was able to eat again.

During that recovery time, I was only on fluids to keep me strong enough for treatment. Then I started implementing purées and soups. Then came soft foods like pasta, scrambled eggs, and oats. Finally, I was cleared to start solid foods.

I was terrified, as I’d choked before when I tried eating. But my medical team was in the room, supporting me and giving me hope that I’d be OK. They helped me overcome my fear. They had me successfully eat a sandwich before getting discharged.
Being Discharged and Getting Back to My Life

The fear of choking was always there, especially in my first few months after that crisis. I took it slow. I tried to eat as many soft foods as I could. When I found myself unable to chew or swallow, I stopped trying.

sections.heading: Be Aware
content: Before my diagnosis, when I couldn’t swallow, I drank water, trying to force the food down my throat. This made my throat muscles even more tired. Eventually, I’d choke and stop.

Now I’m aware that if I have difficulty chewing or swallowing, it means I shouldn’t force it. My muscles are tired and I should rest. I can take my meds and not talk, eat, or drink for at least 10 minutes. That allows my muscles to regain energy to allow me to eat.
bullets: Your muscles get tired when they’re exacerbated, and evenings are often the worst time. I recommend avoiding foods at that time that need extra chewing (like steak), sandwiches that aren’t soft, and things that are hard to swallow (like popcorn).

Never take meds without consulting your doctor. Even a cough drop could have negative effects. Don’t take drugs that have magnesium if they aren’t prescribed by your medical team. Read the ingredient list when you shop for anything to eat.
Don’t talk while you chew. It seems silly, but it’s extra effort on your mouth muscles.

content: If you can’t swallow, go to your nearest ER.
If you don’t know what’s safe to eat when you have swallowing issues, check with a registered dietitian or nutritionist familiar with MG. They can create a nutrition program suitable for your needs.
Remember to give yourself credit. This chronic illness requires a lot of planning, awareness, and patience. You’re doing your best!
